summary: An interview with Owen Jones discussing his campaigning efforts and views on the political landscape.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with two men sitting in a cozy, warmly lit room, engaged in a conversation. The man on the left, wearing a light grey sweater with a red and yellow circular badge, listens attentively to the man on the right, who is dressed in a dark blue sweater and holding a microphone with the brand name 'RODE' visible. The background features a bookshelf filled with books and a lamp, creating a comfortable and intellectual atmosphere. Text appears on the screen, identifying the man on the right as 'Michael Walker @michaeljswalker' and the man on the left as 'Owen Jones @owenjones84,' indicating their social media handles. The scene then transitions to an outdoor setting where two young men walk side by side, both wearing backpacks and badges similar to those seen earlier. The man on the left wears a purple shirt, while the man on the right sports a dark blue shirt. They walk past a residential area with houses and greenery, suggesting a casual, everyday environment. The video then shifts to a group of people gathered outdoors, with one man in a blue jacket taking a selfie with a smartphone. The smartphone screen displays a red and white pamphlet with the text '4 for the many not the few,' indicating a political or social campaign. The group appears engaged and focused on the selfie, with some holding pamphlets, reinforcing the theme of activism or community involvement. The video captures a blend of personal interaction, casual outdoor activities, and a sense of collective purpose.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker from "Navara Media" introducing Owen Jones. A second male speaker joins, and they discuss being out in "Co-Idun" and "pounding those streets, knocking on those...no door unknocked", praising a phenomenal army. Their tone is casual and enthusiastic. A snippet of music plays, adding to a sense of excitement.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with two men sitting in a cozy, warmly lit room, engaged in a conversation. The man on the left, wearing a light gray sweater with a checkered shirt underneath and a red and yellow sticker on his chest, gestures animatedly as he speaks. The man on the right, dressed in a dark blue sweater, listens attentively, holding a microphone with the 'KODAK' logo. The background features a bookshelf filled with books and a lamp, creating a comfortable atmosphere. The scene transitions to an outdoor setting where a man in a light gray shirt with suspenders and a checkered shirt underneath is conversing with a woman in a white top and black jacket. The background shows parked cars and residential buildings, indicating a suburban neighborhood. The video then returns to the indoor setting, where the two men continue their discussion, with the man on the left speaking and the man on the right listening. The scene shifts again to an outdoor residential area, where a man in a blue jacket is seen walking past houses with red flowers in the garden. The video concludes with a man in a purple shirt and gray pants walking along the sidewalk, carrying a white object, with houses and parked cars in the background. The overall atmosphere is casual and conversational, with a focus on the interactions between the individuals in both indoor and outdoor settings.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio starts with a male speaker stating that Corby had a 150-vote majority for Gavin Barwell, whom he identifies as a Tory housing minister. He speaks in a fairly casual tone, asserting that Tories have a good record on housing but that there are "too many affordable homes". He mentions a "huge army out". He describes the crowd as young and diverse. The speaker suggests that the crowd may have experienced the "sharp end" of Barwell's policies, and that it swept through the constituency, contrasting the Tory's money with the army's people on the ground.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with two men sitting in a cozy, warmly lit room, engaged in a conversation. The man on the left, wearing a light grey sweater with a checkered shirt underneath and a red and yellow circular badge on his chest, holds a microphone labeled 'RODE.' The man on the right, dressed in a dark blue sweater, listens attentively and occasionally responds, gesturing with his hands. The background features a bookshelf filled with books and decorative items, a lamp, and a mirror, creating a comfortable and intimate atmosphere. The scene then transitions to an outdoor setting where a group of people, including a woman in a blue jacket and a man in a beige jacket, are walking along a residential street. The woman appears to be speaking to the group, who are carrying pamphlets and seem engaged in the conversation. The video then returns to the indoor setting, where the two men continue their discussion, with the man on the left now speaking and gesturing with his hands while the man on the right listens attentively. The background remains consistent, maintaining the cozy ambiance of the room. The video captures a blend of indoor and outdoor interactions, highlighting the dynamic between the two men and the group of people in the residential area.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker describing "a racket of vested interests" followed by acknowledgment of receiving a flyer from a relief worker. A female speaker then joins, dismissing the volunteer as a robot and highlighting the "huge army" of campaigners across the country, though expressing burnout. She notes the novelty of many volunteers, young people in their twenties who are campaigning for the first time. The clip closes with a male voice saying "amazing." Background noise consistent throughout the clip suggests an outdoor environment with sounds of general commotion.

events_list.video_caption: In a cozy, warmly lit pub, two men are engaged in a lively conversation. The man on the left, wearing a light grey sweater with a checkered shirt underneath and a red and yellow circular badge, holds a glass of beer and gestures animatedly as he speaks. The man on the right, dressed in a dark blue sweater, holds a microphone with the brand name "RODE" visible, indicating he is conducting an interview. The background is filled with bookshelves, a lamp, and other patrons, creating a relaxed and social atmosphere. As the conversation progresses, the man on the left takes a sip of his beer, while the man on the right listens attentively, occasionally nodding and responding. The scene captures a casual yet engaging interaction between the two, set against the backdrop of a bustling pub environment.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker starting an interview and referring to a campaign. The male speaker has a slightly questioning tone, asking, "Have you been pleasantly surprised?" A second male speaker answers, noting he supported the campaign from the beginning, but expressing doubt. He acknowledges the angry comments that might point this out. His tone then shifts to a more positive assessment of the campaign, describing it as having proven him wrong. He refers to an implosion, and says the campaign is offering a vision, mentioning education, health, housing, and jobs. The speaker summarizes the message as asking those at the top to spread their money and allow a living wage to happen. The speaker continues, implying a worry people's minds were made up, preventing the message from being heard.

events_list.video_caption: In a cozy, warmly lit café, two men are engaged in a conversation. The man on the left, wearing a light grey sweater with a checkered shirt underneath and a red and yellow circular badge on his chest, speaks animatedly into a microphone held by the man on the right. The man on the right, dressed in a dark blue sweater, listens attentively, occasionally nodding in agreement. The background is filled with bookshelves, a lamp, and other patrons, creating a relaxed and intimate atmosphere. The scene captures a moment of dialogue, with the man on the left gesturing expressively while the man on the right maintains a calm demeanor, holding the microphone steadily. The setting suggests a casual yet focused discussion, possibly for a podcast or interview, with the café's ambiance enhancing the overall mood.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip opens with a male speaker discussing being proven decisively wrong, expressing relief that "a lot of people have just changed their minds and have been inspired," contrary to his fear of poor polling numbers in the early twenties. He emphasizes the power of a "grassroots movement and inspiring vision". Another male speaker adds that people are more receptive to socialism than previously believed, then humorously exclaims, "They bloody love it!" Following this, the first male speaker requests a bit of "clairvoyance". Throughout this exchange, a consistent, yet quiet ambient sound, is present.

events_list.video_caption: In a cozy, warmly lit pub, two men are engaged in a lively conversation. The man on the left, wearing a light grey sweater with a checkered shirt underneath and a red and yellow circular badge on his chest, holds a glass of beer and takes a sip while listening attentively. The man on the right, dressed in a dark blue sweater with a small red logo on the chest, holds a microphone with the "KODE" logo, indicating he is conducting an interview. The scene captures a casual yet engaging interaction, with the interviewee occasionally glancing at the interviewer, suggesting a dynamic exchange of ideas.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio features a single male speaker asking for predictions about newspaper headlines for the upcoming election day. His tone is conversational and inquisitive. His request specifically mentions "The Sun," "Daily Mail," and "The Guardian." Sounds of general public ambiance are heard in the background, suggesting an interview taking place in a public location.

events_list.video_caption: In a cozy, warmly lit pub, two men are engaged in a lively conversation. The man on the left, wearing a grey sweater with a red and yellow badge, leans forward, animatedly speaking into a microphone held by the man on the right, who is dressed in a dark blue sweater. The background is bustling with patrons, some seated and others standing, contributing to the pub's lively atmosphere. The scene is enriched by bookshelves and a mirror, adding to the pub's character. As the conversation progresses, a newspaper headline from "The Sun" appears on the screen, reading "DON'T CHUCK BRITAIN IN THE COR-BIN," with a note clarifying it as the actual headline. This is followed by another newspaper headline from "The Daily Mail," stating "LET'S REIGNITE BRITISH SPIRIT," accompanied by a subheading about tactical voting. The men's expressions and gestures suggest a dynamic and engaging discussion, with the newspaper headlines adding a layer of context to their conversation.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with one male speaker. He asks what the headline will be in The Sun, then another male speaker says: "Corbyn will nationalize your mother," and, "He will force everyone to change their first name to Osama Bin Laden." Then the first male speaker asks what the headline will be in The Daily Mail, and the second male speaker says: "Every street in Britain will have to be renamed Vladimir Lenin is welcome," and, "We should all wear Soviet berets." The audio takes place outdoors in public as background ambient noise of people talking can be heard.

events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker talking about "the Guardian," clarifying it "is a liberal newspaper, not a socialist newspaper." He mentions some of the writers the Guardian has on the left. In the background, there is ambient noise with a moderate and consistent rhythm, creating a setting that is potentially outdoors and public.

events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip opens with speech from a male voice discussing the Guardian's story about Labour, saying "wholeheartedly about Labour in this election," and advocating to "vote Labour". This male voice then discusses election polls with another male voice. The first male voice hopes for "solid... Labour's done something good." The clip concludes with the mention that the content is being released on election day, amidst general background sounds that are difficult to make out.

events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a man in a moderately agitated tone suggesting they shouldn't waste the opportunity to speak with Owen Jones. He asks, "What should people be doing this afternoon?". Owen Jones responds with pleading in his voice, requesting viewers look at his "puppy dog pleading eyes." He emphasizes the importance of doing "every last thing you can do" to get people to vote for Labour, finishing with the question, "then when?" Background noises suggest an outdoor environment with a crowd and general ambient chatter.

events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker passionately advocating for a labor party, promising "an inspiring vision" and improvements in housing, jobs, poverty reduction, education, and social care. He urges listeners to "drag" people to the polling station and highlights the support from younger voters, non-voters, and women. Simultaneously, indistinct background sounds create an ambient environment. This transitions into speech from another male.

events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with someone describing how older Tories believe young people are lazy and won't vote, urging them to prove this wrong. They emphasize the importance of voting for change and influencing others to do the same, speaking with urgency. Then, someone thanks the speaker and mentions that the clip will be watched on Facebook. Sounds of background chatter and what seems like general conversation suggest the setting of the clip is a public space, such as a rally or a gathering.

events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker who is excited and enthusiastic, providing a political message and ideas for how to participate in political action. He suggests messaging people who haven't been talked to about politics recently, and visiting a website to find areas that need help. Another male speaker then speaks, sharing that the process of political participation is easy, and highlighting the fact that new people will be paired with experienced participants. He also says that he believes it will "change the world." The first speaker comes back and says that voting is Friday if you vote conservative.

events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with speech, featuring a male speaker who encourages listeners by saying, "You've done everything you can do for socialism today," suggesting listeners to "sit back, relax" and tune into the "Navara's all night live election coverage." The tone is positive and promotional. Following the speech, a short musical interlude plays. The genre seems ambient with a slightly unsettling mood.  Afterward, a distinct sound effect is heard.
